In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

```julia
using Dates # Import the Dates module to work with dates and times in Julia

function timezone_bumper(dt, bump = 3)
    if isa(dt, DateTime) # Check if dt is a DateTime object
        return dt + Hour(bump) # Add bump hours to the timestamp
    elseif isa(dt, Date) # Check if dt is a Date object
        error("timezone_bumper only accepts DateTime objects") # Throw an error if dt is not a DateTime object
    end
end
```

This function will add `bump` hours to the provided datetime (`dt`) and return the result. If `bump` is not specified, it defaults to 3 hours. If `dt` is not a DateTime object, an error message is returned.
